title: `forge create` verification cannot use foundry.toml etherscan config
body:
### Component

Forge

### Have you ensured that all of these are up to date?

- [X] Foundry
- [X] Foundryup

### What version of Foundry are you on?

forge 0.2.0 (d7d2901 2023-11-29T00:17:24.163799000Z)

### What command(s) is the bug in?

forge create --verify

### Operating System

macOS (Apple Silicon)

### Describe the bug

Currently, defining etherscan API keys in `foundry.toml` cannot be used with `forge create --verify`.

Example:

```foundry.toml
[etherscan]
scroll_sepolia = { key = "goodAPIKey", url = "https://api-sepolia.scrollscan.com/api/", chain = 534351 }
```

```bash
forge create Contract --rpc-url scroll_sepolia --private-key 0xabc123 --verify --legacy
[â ’] Compiling...
No files changed, compilation skipped
Error:
ETHERSCAN_API_KEY must be set
```

After some digging, the reason for this behavior is that create does a "verify preflight check", but doesn't load `foundry.toml`'s etherscan config until it actually runs the verification. So, you _must_ define the API key as an env var or as a flag to the `create` command in order to pass the preflight check and deploy the contract.

Now, you also can't pass in a dummy API keys. The env var and command flag taking precedence over `foundry.toml`'s etherscan values. (And so does the `etherscan_api_key` value in a profile.)

As far as I can tell, the values do get read, but `get_etherscan_config_with_chain()` in `config/src/lib.rs` defaults to using an env var if available.

This approach seems a little counter intuitive since Etherscan now has a fragmented API Key setup across lots of chains, and it's easy to pull env vars into the `foundry.toml` file.

I will follow-up with a PR suggesting a change that worked for the example above.
